isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION CARRIERS: ROCKWELL - DISASSEMBLE - REMOVE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE FROM CARRIER

svcproc.title: REMOVE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE FROM CARRIER

step1.para: Fasten a yoke or flange bar to the input yoke or flange. The bar will hold the drive pinion in position when the nut is removed ( Figure 23).

figure.caption: Figure 23. Fasten Yoke or Flange Bar to Input Yoke or Flange

step1.para: Remove the nut and washer * from the drive pinion.
Remove the yoke or flange bar.

Remove the yoke or flange from the drive pinion. If the yoke or flange is tight on the pinion, use a puller for removal ( Figure 24). The yoke puller is available through P.D.C. Refer to SPECIAL TOOLS.

figure.caption: Figure 24. Remove Yoke or Flange From Drive Pinion

caution.para: Do not use a hammer or mallet to loosen and remove the yoke or flange. A hammer or mallet can damage the parts and cause runout or alignment problems.

step1.para: Remove the capscrews and washers that hold the bearing cage in the carrier ( Figure 25).

figure.caption: Figure 25. Remove Capscrews and Washers Holding Bearing Cage in Carrier

warning.para: Wear safe eye protection. Do not hit steel parts with a steel hammer. Parts can break and cause injury.

step1.para: Remove the cover * and seal assembly and gasket * from the bearing cage ( Figure 26). If the cover * is tight on the bearing cage, use a brass drift and hammer for removal.

figure.caption: Figure 26. Remove Cover and Seal Assembly and Gasket From Bearing Cage

step1.para: If the pinion seal is damaged, remove the seal from the cover *. Use a press and sleeve or seal driver. If a press is not available, use a screwdriver or small pry bar for removal. Discard the pinion seal.

note.para: If the carrier does not have a cover and seal assembly, the pinion seal will be mounted in the outer bore of the bearing cage. Remove the seal after the drive pinion is removed from the bearing cage.

step1.para: Remove the drive pinion, bearing cage and shims from the carrier. If the bearing cage is tight in the carrier, use the following procedures to loosen the cage ( Figure 27).

figure.caption: Figure 27. Remove Drive Pinion, Bearing Cage and Shims From Carrier

warning.para: Wear safe eye protection. Do not hit steel parts with a steel hammer. Parts can break and cause injury.

step2.para: Hit the bearing cage at several points around the flange area with a leather, plastic or rubber mallet.

Some bearing cages have threaded puller screw holes * in the mounting flange. Puller screws can be used to loosen and pull a tightly fitted cage from the carrier. If puller screws are used, clean the threaded holes before the puller screws are installed ( Figure 28).

caution.para: Do not use a pry bar to remove the bearing cage from the carrier. A pry bar can damage the bearing cage, shims and carrier.

step1.para: If the shims are in good condition, keep the shims together for use later when the carrier is assembled.

If shims are to be discarded because of damage, first measure the total thickness of the pack. Make a note of the dimension. The dimension will be needed to calculate the depth of the drive pinion in the carrier when the gear set is installed.
